Node

Introduction to Node

Node, also often called Node.js, is a JavaScript run-time environment built on Chrome's V8 JavaScript engine. The Node run-time environment includes everything you need to execute a program written in JavaScript. Node allows you to run JavaScript as a standalone application without the need to use a browser.

The V8 JavaScript engine takes your JavaScript code and converts it into faster machine code. Machine code is low-level, meaning the computer can run the code without first needing to interpret it.

To install Node, go to the following link and download the version required: https://nodejs.org/en/

Open the terminal to confirm the version of Node installed:

                        
    $ node --version

Getting Started

Once Node has been installed, it's time to see it working. Create a file named 'app.js', and paste the following code:

                        
    console.log('Node is working!');

Open the terminal and run the following command to output the message in the console.log:

                        
    $ node app.js
